awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Groundwater Age Distributions: Exploring Watershed Scale Subsurface Systems
awd_abstract_narration: Residence times in groundwater systems are referred to in terms of groundwater age and used to diagnose both natural and anthropogenically impacted groundwater behavior.  Environmental tracers are employed as proxies to estimate groundwater age, but their application almost always assumes a steady, stationary flow.  The effects and importance of transient flow are not accounted for and are unknown.  This project addresses non-stationary flows in complex watersheds by accounting for the impacts of temporal variability of weather and climate forcings on groundwater flow and age transport.  It uses a two-fold approach.  Synthetic systems will be modeled using five-dimensional (5-D), generalized groundwater age models (3-space, 1-time, 1-age) in order to build understanding of controlling processes on groundwater age distributions (GWAD).  In transient flows, GWADs are functions of both the time of observation and the time at which observed water entered the system.  Preliminary theoretical results show that transient flows bring in processes at all scales, with significant impacts on long-term memory.  Then two instrumented and monitored natural watershed systems in the upper Rio Grande of Colorado and New Mexico will be studied.  One of these sites is located in the Jemez Mountains of north-central New Mexico and this watershed is part of a Critical Zone Observatory (CZO) funded by NSF.  The type, time, and location of new chemical and isotopic tracer measurements will be optimized based on their preliminary 5-D groundwater age models.  These applications to natural watersheds will involve undergraduates, link models with data, test the underlying theory and its application, and elucidate how best to use the available suite of tracer methods for GWAD estimation in non-stationary systems.  Innovative mathematical solution methods to the 5-D generalized age equations will be developed and tested, including the use of Laplace transforms on age in order to reduce dimensionality.  Extensions of these concepts and approaches to residence time distributions in other hydrologic applications, including stream ecology, and to atmospheric science and oceanography where similar problems are encountered in the context of environmental tracers and circulation models, are anticipated.

As groundwater moves through the environment from recharge to discharge at a spring, stream or lake it gets older. Groundwater age can be detected using environmental tracers like carbon-14, which decays with time, and even the chemistry of the water as it dissolves rock. For some tracers the clock is initiated when water crosses the water table and recharges the aquifer. The clock for other tracers and groundwater chemistry starts when the water infiltrates the soil after a precipitation event. Since groundwater moves slowly groundwater age can get quite old for longer flow paths, even hundreds to thousands of years. Tracers also can tell us something about the trajectory of flow paths followed by groundwater as it moves from recharge to discharge. When water from two flow paths mixes their ages mix as well. When it is many flow paths that mingle underground the resulting mixture contains a distribution of ages, sometimes from as young as weeks to as old as thousands of years. Mixing is common. Many water samples taken at springs or wells, or in upwelling groundwater below a stream or lake, have a wide distribution of ages. Hydrologists must make some assumptions to interpret the age measurements and reconstruct flow paths. A common assumption is that flow paths, and rates of flow, have remained the same since the water recharged. Human impacts, weather, and even changing climate (for older water) cause flow paths and rates to fluctuate and change over time. This project examined the impact of these dynamic fluctuations and changes on groundwater age and the interpretation of age through measurements of environmental tracers and chemistry.

The project not only examined watershed and basin scale flow, as described above, but the much shorter flow paths and residence times of stream hyporheic zones. This is a region of sediment below and alongside a stream, on the scale of meters to tens of meters, where stream water enters the subsurface, moves through the sediments, and eventually returns to the stream. It is a very active  zone for biogeochemical reactions including the processing of stream nutrients. Groundwater age and residence time are different words for essentially the same thing.

We used mathematical modeling and field observations at both the watershed and hyporheic zone scales to develop a better understanding of how dynamically changing flow influences age and residence time. Relatively small fluctuations in time, even though importantly affecting the flow in a system, can have minimal effects on both actual age distributions and ages estimated with environmental tracers. As the intensity of fluctuation increases, still within the bounds observed in natural systems, age distributions for water from shallow parts of a system (e.g. spring flow in a watershed, upwelling groundwater in a hyporheic zone) show high sensitivity to dynamic flow conditions, leading to considerable changes in age distribution over time. In particular, transient flow can lead to emergence of multiple peaks of age (i.e., several different, non-overlapping ages in a sample) that would not be present under steady flow conditions. Age distributions for water samples from deep within a studied systems may also have multiple peaks, but they tend to not change over time even for large fluctuations in whatever process is forcing flow to change over time. Deep water is less sensitive to these forcings, which typically occur at or near the surface (recharge in watersheds; water levels and flow rates in streams). Floods were considered as one of the forcings for meander hyporheic zones.
